glossary criminal - within this training, refers to a person who builds hme for criminal purposes, such as assassination or to assist in a robbery chlorate/perchlorate mixture - an hme mixture containing chlorates or perchlorates as core ingredients commercial/military explosives - manufactured explosives that have standardized chemical and explosive properties explosives - also called the main charge, consists of either an explosive or combustible material fuel - a substance that contributes energy and heat to a chemical reaction hobbyist - within this training, refers to a person who builds hme accidentally or for experimental purposes homemade explosive (hme) - explosives created by combining common household ingredients to create a combustible material improvised explosive device (ied) - a device placed or fabricated in an improvised manner incorporating destructive, lethal, noxious, pyrotechnic, or incendiary chemicals and designed to destroy, incapacitate, harass, or distract initiator - the first explosive in the explosive train of an ied that starts the actual explosive event nitrate mixture - an hme mixture that contains nitrates as a core ingredient oxidizer - oxidizers yield oxygen when combined with fuels or other explosive ingredients, producing energy peroxide mixture - an hme mixture that contains peroxides as a core ingredient pies - power source, initiator, explosives, switch power source - an internal energy source that stores or releases electrical, mechanical, or chemical energy to initiate an ied reactant - substances participating in a chemical reaction; after the reaction, the reactant will have changed chemically from one formula to another switch - the part of an ied that arms and fires sequences of the ied terrorist - within this training, refers to a person who builds hme to further a terrorist agenda

hme production information is readily available select each object on the desk. then, select next to continue. websites terrorist publications terrorist publications social media terrorist publications terrorist organizations publish propaganda in the form of “how-to” magazines with the production detail of a fashion magazine you might find in the grocery store, but the featured articles include instructions on how to evade police or what chemicals are needed to construct homemade explosives and ieds. did you know? the boston marathon bombers, dzhokar and tamerlan tsarnaev acquired some of the knowledge they needed to construct pressure cooker bombs from terrorist publications. websites websites dedicated to the construction of ieds that use homemade explosives proliferate across the internet. not all of them are necessarily tied to terrorist organizations, though some do. others are intended to simply disseminate information—but this can be just as dangerous, because this information in the wrong hands can be devastating. did you know? when “how to make homemade explosives” is searched in googletm, 1,950 results are populated in 0.30 seconds. social media an increasing source of terrorist recruitment and training is through social media. using internet forums, chat services, and social media platforms, terrorists can reach out to—and stay in communication with—potential attackers. did you know? social media is thought to have played a role in the coordination of the 2015 paris attacks at a concert venue, multiple restaurants, and a stadium.

ask an expert: considerations select each button. then, select next to continue. toxic noxious corrosive flammable oxidizer explosive toxic toxic many precursor chemicals are potentially harmful if ingested or if absorbed through the skin. never drink or eat around precursor chemicals, and be careful not to handle them in any capacity. corrosive corrosive chemicals can cause damage to the skin if not handled safely. sulfic acid is one example of a material with corrosive properties. however, be aware that some other substances may be corrosive only under certain circumstances or when found in combination with other chemicals. corrosive flammable the flammability of hme and precursor chemicals varies widely. some of these substances may be ignited by as little as a small spark, while others require sustained exposure to flames before a reaction occurs. it is often not possible to predict what level of exposure could ignite these substances, as it varies considerably depending on the methods used for production. flammable oxidizer some precursor chemicals are oxidizers. they are a fire hazard because they can cause combustible materials to ignite more easily by lowering flashpoints and ignition temperatures, enhance combustion, and widen the flammable range of flammable gases and liquids. oxidizer explosive you may sometimes encounter precursor chemicals that have already been combined to form an explosive material. it is not always easy to recognize this, so extreme caution should be exercised when you suspect the presence of hme or their precursor chemicals. explosive noxious many precursor chemicals are dangerous if inhaled and can cause a range of symptoms from shortness of breath to permanent lung damage or even death. the potential for precursor chemicals to be noxious necessitates swift evacuation in cases where suspect substances are present. do not open doors or windows to attempt to dissipate the chemicals. noxious

homemade explosives in ieds select next to continue. improvised explosive device (ied) “a device placed or fabricated in an improvised manner incorporating destructive, lethal, noxious, pyrotechnic, or incendiary chemicals and designed to destroy, incapacitate, harass, or distract.” (source: department of defense joint publication 1-02 dictionary of military and associated terms)

ask an expert select each question. then, select next to continue. faq 1 how is hme different from commercial or military explosives? faq 1 how is hme different from commercial or military explosives? faq 1 how is hme different from commercial or military explosives? faq 1 how is hme different from commercial or military explosives? faq 2 why would individuals choose hme over other options? faq 2 why would individuals choose hme over other options? faq 2 why would individuals choose hme over other options? faq 2 why would individuals choose hme over other options? faq 3 are there programs that prevent the sale of precursor chemicals? faq 3 are there programs that prevent the sale of precursor chemicals? faq 3 are there programs that prevent the sale of precursor chemicals? faq 3 are there programs that prevent the sale of precursor chemicals? answer answer despite their added danger, homemade explosives have several advantages for individuals wanting to cause harm. they are easier to acquire, and it is also easier to conceal intent by purchasing precursor chemicals that are less likely to alert authorities to an impending attack. faq 2 why would individuals choose hme over other options? faq 2 why would individuals choose hme over other options? in addition to being largely homemade and often more readily available, homemade explosives differ from military and commercial explosives in that they are frequently less stable and more likely to react unexpectedly. some homemade explosives are particularly dangerous and have been known to explode with only light handling or after being dropped. terrorists aren’t the only people injuring themselves either. every year, dozens of people injure themselves or others while experimenting with homemade explosives. faq 1 how is hme different from commercial or military explosives? faq 1 how is hme different from commercial or military explosives? obp offers a community outreach program called the bomb-making materials awareness program (bmap). bmap is a government-industry partnership to prevent terrorism by securing chemicals that can be used to make homemade explosives used in improvised explosive devices (ieds). many chemicals are so common that it is impractical to regulate their sale, which terrorists and criminals exploit. through this voluntary program, bmap educates industry partners to prevent the misuse of these chemicals by: building a network of aware and vigilant partners throughout the private sector; inventory and sales transaction security awareness; and suspicious activity reporting. these employees then help to serve as the “nation’s eyes and ears,” acting as force multipliers in detecting and reporting suspicious activity. for more information visit: www.dhs.gov/bomb-making-materials-awareness-program. faq 3 are there programs that prevent the sale of precursor chemicals? faq 3 are there programs that prevent the sale of precursor chemicals?

military and commercial explosives are manufactured to be stable and designed to be transported and stored, whereas hme typically isn’t designed for transportation and has a shelf life. got it! got it! module 2: introduction select next to continue. three types of individuals who make hme and their motives

the three types of manufacturers select each type of manufacturer. then, select next to continue. hobbyists hobbyists hobbyists criminals criminals criminals terrorists terrorists terrorists hobbyists hobbyists make up the majority of hme users domestically. this category includes bored teenagers—to makeshift inventors—to adults building explosives for “fun.” the hobbyist may be making homemade explosives using instructions found on the internet, or, in other cases, simply combining chemicals to cause a reaction. every year, dozens of people in the united states are wounded or killed by accidental explosions caused by experimenting with homemade explosives. case study case study case study hobbyists case study long beach, ca, 2008 long beach police responded to a call about an explosion in a suburban home. on arrival, they discovered a 15-year-old boy who had been injured in an explosion. it was eventually discovered that the boy, with the assistance of a 14-year-old friend, had been manufacturing homemade tatp using instructions they found on the internet. neither boy had had previous contact with law enforcement authorities, nor a previous history of violence. image 1 of 6 suburban home where teens constructed hme image 2 of 6 desk covered in precursor materials image 3 of 6 marker bomb with gun powder image 4 of 6 cardboard box containing materials needed to construct tatp image 5 of 6 peroxide, toilet bowl cleaner, and acetone image 6 of 6 tatp being crystalized in a fridge unit criminals what separates a criminal from a terrorist is mainly motive; criminals typically use homemade explosives in an ied in support of criminal activities as opposed to largely ideological ones. for example, criminals may use an ied with homemade explosives to create a distraction, assassinate a rival, intimidate or threaten someone, damage property, and so on. case study case study case study criminals case study escondido, california 2010 the “bomb factory” case george djura jakubec was arrested by law enforcement after a gardener at his residence was injured by an accidental explosion of highly volatile explosive material in jakubec’s backyard. a federal indictment charged jakubec with eight counts relating to the unlawful manufacture and possession of destructive devices at his escondido, california residence, the robbery or attempted robbery of four san diego county banks, and possessing a firearm during and in relation to two of those bank robberies. jakubec pled guilty. specifically regarding the destructive devices charge, jakubec admitted that he illegally manufactured and possessed certain high explosives, including significant quantities of hexamethylene tiperoxide diamine (hmtd), pentaerythitol tetranitrate (petn), and erythritol tetranitrate (etn). image 1 of 5 countertop covered in bomb-making materials image 2 of 5 cluttered room filled with bomb-making materials image 3 of 5 garage filled with bomb-making materials image 4 of 5 large containers filled with sulfuric acid image 5 of 5 jars of hexamethylene triperoxide diamine (hmtd) terrorists terrorist deployment of hme remains a high-risk possibility. while terrorists make up a minority of hme users, their motives are generally to kill or injure as many people as possible, making them particularly dangerous as a category. terrorists may operate individually or as part of a larger group; groups may have advanced production techniques available to them. even lone wolf terrorists, however, are capable of manufacturing and functioning devastating devices. case study case study case study terrorists case study paris, france 2002 richard reid (shoe bomber) richard reid used an ied with hme within the heel of his shoe in an attempt to attack a flight from paris to miami in 2002. the ied contained hme as both the initiator and the explosive components, crafted in a way that prevented premature detonation. image 1 of 4 the shoe worn by richard reid image 2 of 4 mugshot of richard reid image 3 of 4 roll of white substance used in shoe bomb image 4 of 4 bottom of the shoe pulled back to reveal the explosive
few incidents involve terrorists cc cc cc select next to continue. who is doing the majority of the manufacturing?

decide whether each case is best classified as a terrorist, criminal, or hobbyist enterprise. when finished, select next to continue. activity: classify the incident case 1 of 3: bombing at rugged co. factory a huge explosion recently took place at a factory that manufactures sport utility vehicles. all indications are that the attack was meant to send some kind of message to the survivors. lucy gonzalez is a member of a violent animal and eco-rights group, which has been connected with a number of incidents in the state of washington. gonzalez is suspected of assisting in acquiring materials for construction of an ied using homemade explosives in pursuit of the group’s goals. criminal profile case classification terrorist terrorist terrorist criminal criminal criminal hobbyist hobbyist hobbyist that’s correct! sorry, that’s not the best answer. this case is best classified as a terrorist case. case 2 of 3: shenandoah campground explosion rangers were called to the site of camp area 5 in shenandoah national park after a large explosion occurred in a clearing near the bath stations. witnesses claimed that a person, who was behaving as if intoxicated, appeared to be detonating explosive material in the clearing. jori unger has a history of experimenting with explosive materials on his own time. on numerous occasions, neighbors have alerted law enforcement after hearing a loud “bang” from his property. unger has a social media channel he runs where he demonstrates the effects of the explosions set to music. he recently told a local new channel he builds the bombs “for fun.” criminal profile case classification terrorist terrorist terrorist criminal criminal criminal hobbyist hobbyist hobbyist case 3 of 3: burberry bank explosion a bomb that was suspected to contain hme was detonated near the burberry bank. the bomb appears to have been a decoy of some kind, intended to distract authorities from a bank robbery that occurred at the bank. while it doesn’t appear the bomb was meant to inflict mass casualties, several people were injured. daniel conner is a thief and con-man with a long rap sheet. he is connected to several robberies in the area. criminal profile case classification terrorist terrorist terrorist criminal criminal criminal hobbyist hobbyist hobbyist that’s correct! sorry, that’s not the best answer. this case is best classified as a hobbyist case. that’s correct! sorry, that’s not the best answer. this case is best classified as a criminal case.

contact use the arrows to step through the conversation. then, select next. give me a hand, will you? i’m trying to move some of these bags. are you sure that’s a good idea? yeah, we should be careful. that stuff looks like it could be dangerous. agreed. let’s back out and call in the bomb squad. i don’t know what this is. it could be drugs or explosives. let’s get the bomb technicians in here to make that call. key concept do not make direct or indirect contact with suspected homemade explosives, precursor chemicals, or production equipment. this includes walking on, moving, or applying unnecessary pressure to unknown substances. got it! got it! got it! got it! got it! got it! watch again watch again watch again watch again watch again watch again

keep flames and sparks away use the arrows to step through the conversation. then, select next. well, there’s something you don’t see every day. is that homemade fireworks? could be. best to be on the safe side. let’s be sure to keep it away from heat or flames. let’s evacuate and call in the bomb squad. key concept keep all flame/spark producing devices away from hme and precursor chemicals. all explosives are sensitive to heat, shock, friction, and electrostatic discharge; however, sensitivity will vary based on the type of explosive. it’s always better to err on the side of safety. got it! got it! got it! got it! got it! got it! watch again watch again watch again watch again watch again watch again

toxic fumes use the arrows to step through the conversation. then, select next. you smell that? it’s awful! what are they cooking, grandma’s special nail polish recipe? i think it’s coming from that pot on the stove. hey, we should get everyone out of here. that could be something dangerous, and i’m not sure it’s safe. let’s call in an expert. key concept homemade explosives and their precursor chemicals may have strange odors. do not stay in a confined area with suspected homemade explosives or their precursor chemicals as their fumes may be toxic. got it! got it! got it! got it! got it! got it! watch again watch again watch again watch again watch again watch again

canine handling tactics use the arrows to step through the conversation. then, select next. i think we should let my dog off-leash to do some searching of the property. maybe he can turn something up. hold up there. i’m not sure that’s a great idea. there are signs that the residents have been experimenting with some chemicals. there may be hazards in there that would harm your partner. i don’t think it’s safe. good point. maybe he should sit this one out. sorry, boy. key concept animals can’t sense pressure plates, tripwires, levers, switches, or other potential traps nor do they understand the need to avoid walking on unknown powders or materials. it is best to keep you and animal partners safe by keeping them away from all potential hazards and by calling in the bomb squad to conduct a search with a robot. got it! got it! got it! got it! got it! got it! watch again watch again watch again watch again watch again watch again

sensitivity use the arrows to step through the conversation. then, select next. it’s so dark here. i can barely see a thing! where’s the light switch? uh… guys… i noticed burns on the suspect outside. and i smell a strong odor of “fish” in here. let’s evacuate and not touch anything until an expert arrives. key concept all explosives are sensitive to heat, shock, friction, and electrostatic discharge; sensitivity will vary based on the type of explosive. do not alter the environment in any way as the homemade explosives may be used in an ied that functions by light sensitivity. do not turn light switches on or off, do not open windows or doors, etc. let the hazardous materials expert conduct the search with a robot. got it! got it! got it! got it! got it! got it! watch again watch again watch again watch again watch again watch again

false assumptions use the arrows to step through the conversation. then, select next. hey, what are these white crystals everywhere? looks like baking soda to me. i don’t know. maybe we should have it checked out. let’s evacuate and call someone in to be sure. key concept treat unknown substances as a hazard until it has been positively identified by the bomb squad. white powders and crystals can be a number of things but, just to be safe…evacuate and call in the experts. in addition, be alert for secondary devices or chemicals that are hidden or not readily apparent. got it! got it! got it! got it! got it! got it! watch again watch again watch again watch again watch again watch again

activity: room #2 complete the activity. when finished, select next to continue. identify the signs of hme being manufactured. appearance: black porous solid, course granules or powder. odor: none. hazard: charcoal powder or dust lasting can cause irritation to the eyes, skin, and upper respiratory tract. charcoal dust in confined areas can create an explosion hazard initiated by heat, sparks, flame, or electrostatic discharge. keep away from moisture. do not mix with oxidizers. avoid dust dispersal. precursor for: may be used as a fuel agent in main charge homemade explosives and incendiaries, black powder, and flash powder mixtures. activated charcoal activated carbon carboraffin karborafin notes: activated charcoal is sometimes used as a medical supplement. equipment unidentified liquid bucket

fuels, oxidizers, and reactants select next to continue. fuels oxidizers reactants oxidizers reactants fuel hobbyists hobbyists make up the majority of hme users domestically. this category includes bored teenagers - to makeshift inventors - to adults building explosives for “fun.” the hobbyist may be making homemade explosives using instructions found on the internet, or, in other cases, simply combining chemicals to cause a reaction. every year, dozens of people in the united states are wounded or killed by accidental explosions caused by experimenting with homemade explosives. continue continue continue hobbyists case study long beach, ca, 2008 long beach police responded to a call about an explosion in a suburban home. on arrival, they discovered a 15-year-old boy who had been injured in an explosion. it was eventually discovered that the boy, with the assistance of a 14-year-old friend, had been manufacturing homemade tatp using instructions they found on the internet. neither boy had had previous contact with law enforcement authorities, nor a previous history of violence. image 1 of 6 image 2 of 6 image 3 of 6 image 4 of 6 image 5 of 6 image 6 of 6 criminals what separates a criminal from a terrorist is mainly motive; criminals typically use homemade explosives in an ied in support of criminal activities as opposed to largely ideological ones. for example, criminals may use an ied with homemade explosives to create a distraction, assassinate a rival, intimidate or threaten someone, damage property, and so on. continue continue continue criminals case study escondido, california 2010 the “bomb factory” case george djura jakubec was arrested by law enforcement after a gardener at his residence was injured by an accidental explosion of highly volatile explosive material in jakubec’s backyard. a federal indictment charged jakubec with eight counts relating to the unlawful manufacture and possession of destructive devices at his escondido, california residence, the robbery or attempted robbery of four san diego county banks, and possessing a firearm during and in relation to two of those bank robberies. jakubec pled guilty. specifically regarding the destructive devices charge, jakubec admitted that he illegally manufactured and possessed certain high explosives, including significant quantities of hexamethylene tiperoxide diamine (hmtd), pentaerythitol tetranitrate (petn), and erythritol tetranitrate (etn). image 1 of 5 image 2 of 5 image 3 of 5 image 4 of 5 image 5 of 5 terrorists terrorist deployment of hme remains a high-risk situation. while terrorists make up a minority of hme users, their motives are generally to kill or injure as many people as possible, making them particularly dangerous as a category. terrorists may operate individually or as part of a larger group; groups may have advanced production techniques available to them. even lone wolf terrorists, however, are capable of manufacturing and functioning devastating devices. continue continue continue terrorists case study paris, france 2002 richard reid (shoe bomber) richard reid used an ied with hme within the heel of his shoe in an attempt to attack a flight from paris to miami in 2002. the ied contained hme as both the initiator and the explosive components, crafted in a way that prevented premature detonation. image 1 of 4 image 2 of 4 image 3 of 4 image 4 of 4
hazardous hme precursors select each drawer to learn more. then, select next to continue. toxic noxious corrosive flammable explosive fuels oxidizers reactants

hazardous hme precursors: fuels select a folder to review its contents. then, select next to continue. fuels fuels contribute energy and heat to the chemical reaction. some fuels (such as sugar, flour, honey, or candle wax) are not hazardous on their own. however, many fuels, such as the ones listed below, pose a danger. always assume a suspect fuel is hazardous. activated charcoal nitromethane ethanol appearance: black porous solid, course granules or powder. odor: none. hazard: charcoal powder or dust lasting can cause irritation to the eyes, skin, and upper respiratory tract. charcoal dust in confined areas can create an explosion hazard initiated by heat, sparks, flame, or electrostatic discharge. keep away from moisture. do not mix with oxidizers. avoid dust dispersal. precursor for: may be used as a fuel agent in main charge homemade explosives and incendiaries, black powder, and flash powder mixtures. activated charcoal also known as: activated carbon carboraffin karborafin notes: activated charcoal is sometimes used as a medical supplement. appearance: colorless, oily liquid. odor: disagreeable. hazard: flammable and somewhat toxic. precursor for: ammonium nitrate and nitromethane (annm). nitromethane also known as: nitrocarbol ch3no2 notes: nitromethane is used widely in the manufacture of pharmaceuticals, pesticides, explosives, fibers, and coatings. nitromethane is also used as a fuel in various motorsports and hobbies, such as drag racing and miniature internal combustion engines in radio control, control line, and free flight model aircraft. appearance: colorless liquid. odor: weak, ethereal, vinous odor. hazard: moderately toxic. causes irritation to the eyes, skin, and respiratory tract. inhalation may result in drowsiness, headache, and throat irritation. ingestion would make the person present symptoms of an intoxication (drunk). excessive ingestion could lead to death. avoid contact with strong oxidizing agents, alkali metals, chlorine, ethylene oxide, and nitric acid. flammable. heat, sparks, or flame may ignite. ethanol notes: in diluted form, ethanol is the principle intoxicant found in alcoholic beverages. when highly concentrated, it is sometimes referred to as a “biofuel,” used in alternative or “green energy” products as an alternative to fossil fuels. also known as: ethyl alcohol alcohol cologne spirit grain alcohol ch3ch2oh

hazardous hme precursors: oxidizers select a folder to review its contents. then, select next to continue. oxidizers oxidizers yield oxygen when combined with fuels or other explosive ingredients, producing energy. they should be considered highly dangerous. hydrogen peroxide potassium chlorate potassium nitrate potassium perchlorate sodium azide sodium chlorate sodium nitrate appearance: colorless liquid. odor: sharp odor. hazard: corrosive. exposure may cause serious injury to the skin, eyes, mucous membranes, and upper respiratory tract. contact with combustibles may result in spontaneous combustion. concentrated hydrogen peroxide may decompose violently when in contact with iron, copper, chromium, and most other metals and their salts and dusts. precursor for: hmtd and tatp. hydrogen peroxide notes: hydrogen peroxide is available in pharmacies, most often in diluted concentrations of water for safety reasons. higher concentrations are available for industrial use. highly concentrated hydrogen peroxide is extremely volatile and dangerous. h2o2 also known as: high-strength hydrogenperoxide hydrogen dioxide hydrogen peroxide (aqueous) hydroperoxide peroxide concentrated hydrogenperoxide (chp) appearance: colorless, lustrous crystals, or white granules or powder. hazard: causes irritation to the skin, eyes, and mucous membranes if exposed to its dust. precursor for: explosive compounds, when mixed with fuel agents or reducing materials. attacks many metals in the presence of water. potassium chlorate notes: potassium chlorate is often used in school laboratories to generate oxygen gas. kclo3 also known as: potassium oxymuriate potcrate appearance: transparent, white, crystalline solid/powder. hazard: moderately toxic. inhalation, ingestion, or contact with skin or eyes with vapors or substance may cause severe injury, burns, or death. its decomposition emits very toxic fumes of nitrogen and potassium oxide. precursor for: gunpowder. mixing it with sodium acetate or sodium hypophosphite may result in an explosion. potassium nitrate and arsenic explode when ignited. it also reacts when mixed with various other chemicals. potassium nitrate notes: potassium nitrate is one of the oldest known industrial compounds, known to both the ancient greeks and egyptians. since the middle ages, it has been used as a food preservative. it is one of the principle ingredients for manufacturing gunpowder. it is also used in fireworks. also known as: saltpeter nitrate of potash kno3 appearance: colorless crystals or white crystalline powder. odor: none. hazard: explosive when mixed with combustible material. highly toxic. avoid skin and eye contact. potassium perchlorate notes: potassium perchlorate is frequently used as an oxidizer in sparklers, fireworks, and similar pyrotechnic devices. also known as: potassium hyperchloride kclo4 appearance: colorless to white hexagonal crystalline solid. description: white solid. odor: odorless in its natural form. gas forms sharp odor. the odor of the gas may not provide sufficient warning of exposure. hazard: acutely toxic if swallowed or inhaled. when mixed with water or an acid, it changes rapidly to a toxic gas with a sharp odor and releases hydrazoic acid. highly combustible at high temperatures or when exposed to shock or friction. sodium azide notes: persons who work on automobiles regularly are at an increased risk of exposure to sodium azide, which is used as a propellant in airbags. sodium azide is also used in the preparation of various chemicals; in agriculture, as a preservative and as a microorganism fumigant; in clinical and research laboratories; in sponge rubber; in detonators; and as an intermediate in explosives manufacturing. also known as: azide azium sodium salt of hydrazoic acid nan3 appearance: yellow or white granules or powder. odor: none. hazard: moderately toxic. avoid eye and skin contact. highly combustible when exposed to heat, shock, or friction. sodium nitrate notes: sodium nitrate exists in large natural deposits in some regions and is extensively mined in chile and peru for industrial purposes. it is a common ingredient in fertilizers, fireworks, and rocket propellant, and has also historically been used as a food additive. also known as: cubic niter chili saltpeter nano3 appearance: colorless to lustrous crystals. odor: none. hazard: moderately toxic. avoid eye and skin contact. sodium chlorate notes: sodium chlorate is used for making herbicides, explosives, dyes, matches, inks, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, defoliants, paper, and leather. also known as: chloric acid calcium salt naclo3

hazardous hme precursors: reactants select a folder to review its contents. then, select next to continue. reactants reactants are substances participating in a chemical reaction. after the reaction, the reactant will have changed chemically from one formula to another. acetone hexamine nitric acid appearance: volatile, colorless liquid. odor: fragrant, flowery, or mint-like. hazard: highly flammable. moderately toxic. exposure to liquid or vapors can cause injury. precursor for: tatp. acetone also known as: dimethyl ketone ketone propane 2-propanone ((ch3)2co) notes: acetone is relatively easily acquired, which makes it an attractive chemical for attackers. it is commonly used in the production of fingernail polish remover, particle board, paint remover, liquid or paste waxes and polishes, detergent, cleaning products, and rubber cement. appearance: white crystalline or dark gray substance. odor: mild ammonia or fish-like smell. hazard: slightly toxic. slight irritating effects to the skin, eyes, and mucous membranes. flammable. precursor for: hmtd and rdx. hexamine c6h12n4 notes: hexamine is often found as solid fuel tablets for cooking. appearance: colorless, yellow, or red fuming liquid. odor: pungent, harsh smell. hazard: combustible materials, metallic powders, hydrogen sulfide, carbides, alcohols. reacts with water to produce heat. corrosive to metals. nitric acid notes: the primary industrial use of nitric acid is for the production of fertilizers. also known as: aqua fortis engravers acid hydrogen nitrate red fuming nitric acid (rfna) white fuming nitric acid (wfna) hno3

three major types of hme mixtures select a tab to review its contents. then, select next to continue. major types of hme mixtures nitrate mixtures nitrate mixtures nitrate mixtures nitrate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures peroxide mixtures peroxide mixtures peroxide mixtures peroxide mixtures peroxide mixtures appearance: often a white crystal. odor: unique, strong chemical smell. examples: triacetone triperoxide (tatp) and hexamethylene triperoxide diamine (hmtd). precursors may be derived from: pool sanitizers, hair coloring, teeth-whitening products, antiseptics. notes: peroxide-based mixtures are often created from household detergents and bleaches. hydrogen peroxide, along with other organic peroxides, mixed with other precursors can create an hme that is extremely sensitive to shock and external stimuli, making the mixture very dangerous. peroxide-based hme mixtures may self-detonate, depending on environmental factors. peroxide-based hmes also have low shelf lives and are often found as white powders or liquids. nitrate mixtures nitrate mixtures nitrate mixtures nitrate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures peroxide mixtures peroxide case study: paris, 2015 the attackers who carried out the attacks in paris on november 13, 2015 used triacetone triperoxide, or tatp. tatp is manufactured using hydrogen peroxide, among other ingredients. tatp is very unstable and dangerous if mishandled. in the case of the paris attacks, the tatp that was included in the attackers’ suicide vests successfully detonated in most of the vests. nitrate mixtures nitrate mixtures nitrate mixtures nitrate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures peroxide mixtures mourners pay tribute responders at the scene location where a suicide vest was found after the paris attacks chlorate/perchlorate mixtures appearance: in pure form, white or off-white powders or crystals. can be any color when mixed with other substances. may be found dissolved in liquid, as in kerosene. odor: typically odorless. examples: ammonium perchlorate, sodium perchlorate (kerosene), potassium chlorate (nitrobenzene). precursors may be derived from: strike-anywhere matches, fireworks, model rocket motors, pool shock. notes: chlorate-based mixtures are created from the chemical reaction of chlorine and oxygen. production of chlorate-based mixtures often begins with the breakdown of liquid bleaches or water-purification additives to extract the pure chlorine. when mixed with various hydroxides, chlorate/perchlorate is produced. chlorate-based mixtures can be components of both main charges and initiators. many chlorate-based mixtures are oxidizers of varying strengths and are blended with fuels and potentially binders. some are relatively insensitive to a reaction, while others are highly unstable. nitrate mixtures nitrate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures peroxide mixtures peroxide mixtures peroxide mixtures nitrate mixtures nitrate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures peroxide mixtures peroxide mixtures exploded remains from the ied fireworks used to build ied chlorate/perchlorate case study: boston, 2013 on april 15, 2013, improvised explosive devices made with a model car remote control, christmas lights, shrapnel, and fireworks were used in pressure cookers and detonated near the boston marathon finish line by tamerian and dzhokhar tsarnaev. potassium perchlorate, collected from commercially available fireworks, were used in the attack that killed three and wounded hundreds of others. nitrate case study: oklahoma city, 1995 on april 19, 1995, a ryder truck parked outside the alfred p. murrah building exploded, killing 168 people, among them 19 children who attended a daycare housed within the building. the primary attacker was later identified as timothy mcveigh, a violent anti-government extremist. according to jim norman, a case agent for this incident, the explosive device was approximately 5,000 pounds of explosive material, which included 4,500 of ammonium nitrate and 300 pounds of tovex that was used as a booster. the device also included three 53-gallon barrels of nitromethane fuel that was mixed with the ammonium nitrate to create ammonium nitrate fuel oil (anfo). the total cost for this device was estimated at $3,450. nitrate mixtures nitrate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures peroxide mixtures peroxide mixtures aerial view of damaged building initial police sketch and mugshot security footage showing the ryder truck notes: fertilizer-based mixtures normally require a booster for initiation, as they are relatively insensitive to shock and external stimulus. fertilizer-based mixtures appear white, yellowish, tan, or pink, and smell like the fuel used. nitrate mixtures appearance: color and form varies. can be found in liquid, crystal, or prill form. odor: may be similar to fuel used. for example, may smell like diesel fuel. in some cases, as when mixed with aluminum powder, may be odorless. examples: ammonium nitrate (an), nitroglycerin (ng), urea nitrate, erythritol tetranitrate (etn). precursors may be derived from: lawn fertilizer, cold packs. nitrate mixtures nitrate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures chlorate/ perchlorate mixtures peroxide mixtures peroxide mixtures

equipment to produce hme select each button to learn more. then, select next to continue. 01 01 01 01 02 02 02 02 03 03 03 03 04 04 04 04 05 05 05 05 06 06 06 06 07 07 07 07 08 08 08 08 09 09 09 09 grinders grinders reduce the granule size of solid components. they are commonly used in the production of various hme powders. examples: mortar/pestle, coffee grinders, and ball mills. mixers and stirrers mixers blend solid components, while stirrers blend liquid components. mixers are commonly used to produce hme powders, while stirrers are used to blend many hme liquids, such as hmtd. examples: common cooking baking mixers (like a kitchenaid) and blenders. stirrers may also come in the form of magnetic stirrers or large buckets. ice baths ice baths cool mixtures that generate heat. many hme mixtures that are heat sensitive may require ice baths to keep them cool. examples: bathtubs, keeping containers in ice chests or coolers, or dry ice. cookers certain hme mixtures may require heating to chemically combine precursors. examples: slow cookers and pressure cookers. filters filters separate the solids from the liquids and are commonly used in the production of peroxide mixtures. examples: filter funnels, coffee filters, and cloth filters. scales to properly measure out proportions of hme precursors, it is often necessary to weigh the ingredients to exact measures. examples: chemical scales that have near-exact accuracy to the hundredth of a gram. drying equipment certain hme mixtures require proper drying during the production process. examples: laying a tarp out in the sunlight and placing the hme precursors or mixtures on the tarp. safety equipment safety equipment provides personal protection for the individual during the production process. examples: gloves, masks, aprons, and goggles. distillers distillers concentrate chemical components with low-level heat. examples: complex scientific equipment, like a rotovap, or household items used in improvised methods, such as a hotplate or a coffee plate.

signs a person has been handling hme or precursors select next to continue. burns on hands or body discolored hands or body strange odors blast injuries trouble breathing or disorientation appearance: black porous solid, course granules or powder. odor: none. hazard: charcoal powder or dust lasting can cause irritation to the eyes, skin, and upper respiratory tract. charcoal dust in confined areas can create an explosion hazard initiated by heat, sparks, flame, or electrostatic discharge. keep away from moisture. do not mix with oxidizers. avoid dust dispersal. precursor for: may be used as a fuel agent in main charge homemade explosives and incendiaries, black powder, and flash powder mixtures. activated charcoal activated carbon carboraffin karborafin notes: activated charcoal is sometimes used as a medical supplement.
module 5: introduction select next to continue. put it all together

choose a story select each character to hear his or her story. then, select next. select a character to step through his or her story. police officer police officer police officer police officer firefighter firefighter firefighter firefighter emergency medical personnel emergency medical personnel emergency medical personnel emergency medical personnel

emergency medical personnel’s story select next to continue. copy. we’re on our way. we’re here. where’s the patient? she’s here. please help! i went for breakfast downstairs and when i came back i found her like this on the floor. i don’t know what to do. she’s responsive but disoriented. we need to get her to the hospital. what’s that? looks like a home chemistry lab setup. it reeks. it’s nothing. just some work stuff. did the patient breathe in any of those fumes? did she ingest anything? we need to know. it could help save her life. i don’t know anything at all. so… the results on that substance you saw in the motel bathroom the other day came back. yeah? what did it turn out to be? soap shavings. weird, right? i’m glad they weren’t making explosives. well, that’s good to know. i’m still glad we made the call to bring in the experts. if that stuff had turned out to be explosives, we could’ve been in trouble. yes, you certainly made the right call. the medical personnel begin to move the patient. that’s when one of them glances into the motel bathroom and notices something strange. the next day… well, i’m not sure either. i don’t think we should get near it until we get clarification. let’s get everyone out of here and notify law enforcement. this stuff could be hazardous.

firefighter’s story select next to continue. 5114 copy. on it and rolling out. well, i see where the smoke is coming from. looks like a small fire. we should look for people in need of rescue and extinguish the flames quickly if possible. once the fire has been extinguished, firefighters begin to assess the interior of the building. they encounter several bags of fertilizer and several additional, unidentified chemicals. looks like someone’s been using this warehouse to stockpile fertilizer and these chemicals. this is not safe. everyone needs to evacuate! unit 51 to dispatch. evacuating scene. possible explosive hazards exist. contact the bomb squad.

police officer’s story select next to continue. sound effect: knock, knock, knock 5332 copy. i’m on it. this is the place. dispatch, 5332 on scene. nothing looks amiss from here. going to investigate further. (knock on door) can i help you, officer? sir, is this your residence? it’s my brother’s. i’m housesitting while he’s away. i see. when will your brother return? next week. how long have you been house sitting? since last week. well, there’s been a complaint about a noise in the area. a loud “pop” — did you hear a loud “pop” about 30 minutes ago? no, officer. do you have any weapons in the house? no, officer. may i come in, sir? umm… sure. come in. look, i don’t want any trouble. it smells strange in here. a strong chemical smell. almost like ammonia. what are you cooking? just an experiment while my brother’s away. look, it’s no big deal. sir, come with me. dispatch, this is 5332. i need back-up. notify the bomb squad. possible hazardous materials on scene. you’re being paranoid. there’s nothing going on. better safe than sorry. let’s go. as the officer scans the room just inside the front door, she smells a chemical odor coming from inside and notices that the resident’s hands look to have possible burn marks. the officer walks into the home. from the doorway, she is able to see into the kitchen area.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
Welcome to the IED Awareness and Safety Procedures course. An improvised explosive device, or IED, is a device placed or fabricated in an improvised manner incorporating destructive, lethal, noxious, pyrotechnic, or incendiary chemicals and designed to destroy, incapacitate, harass, or distract.

This course will teach you how to Identify the purpose, resulting effects, and components of improvised explosive devices,

Describe how to respond to an unattended or suspicious item, and

Explain the proper agency procedures for responding to an unattended or suspicious item.

For information on how to navigate this course, select the “Navigation Tutorial” button in the top right corner of the screen, or select Next to start the course.

This navigation tutorial will demonstrate how to interact with and progress through this course.

The Menu link allows you to access the course outline. You many revisit course screens that you have already viewed simply by selecting any activated link within the Menu.

The Resources tab contains additional websites and documents for you to reference after you complete the course.

The Glossary link contains the definitions of key terms used in this course.

The Help link provides a summary of this navigation tutorial.

The Exit button provides a way for you to leave the course. Your location in the course will be book marked, which allows you to return to the spot where you left off when you return.

The Closed Captioning button allows you to toggle on and off closed captioning for the narration associated with the course.

The Speaker button allows you to toggle on and off the audio associated with the course.

The Play button allows you to play and pause the audio and on-screen visuals.

The Replay button allows you to restart the current on-screen audio and visuals.

The Previous button allows you to return to the previous screen in the course.

The Next button allows you to advance to the next screen in the course.

In this course, you will be required at times to select areas on the screen to access additional information in popup boxes. To close a popup box, select the X button in the upper right hand corner of that popup box.

In a recent month, there were a calculated 233 bomb incidents nationwide. Ninety-five of these were bomb threats; 59 were suspicious items; and 44 were incidents in which bomb squads rendered safe the IEDs and explosive materials.

Since bomb incidents are a part of our world, it is important for each individual to have an understanding of what IEDs are, how they are constructed, and how to safely respond to them.

This training is a vital first step for empowering agency staff to identify potential threats, alert the appropriate authorities, and follow safety procedures.

In a recent month, there were a calculated 233 bomb incidents nationwide. Ninety-five of these were bomb threats; 59 were suspicious items; and 44 were incidents in which bomb squads rendered safe the IEDs and explosive materials.

Welcome to the IED Awareness and Safety Procedures course. An improvised explosive device, or IED, is a device placed or fabricated in an improvised manner incorporating destructive, lethal, noxious, pyrotechnic, or incendiary chemicals and designed to destroy, incapacitate, harass, or distract.

This course will teach you how to Identify the purpose, resulting effects, and components of improvised explosive devices,

Describe how to respond to an unattended or suspicious item, and

Explain the proper agency procedures for responding to an unattended or suspicious item.

For information on how to navigate this course, select the “Navigation Tutorial” button in the top right corner of the screen, or select Next to start the course.
